"Risk Management Plan

Silver Eagle Refining, Evanston Refinery



This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been prepared for the Silver Eagle Refining (SER) Evanston Refinery, to comply with the US EPA Risk Management Program regulations in 40 CFR Part 68. SER has one covered process under the Risk Management Program (LPG storage); the covered process may contain any of three ""regulated substances"" at any time (butane, propane, or flammable mixture).



The SER Evanston Refinery is a small petroleum refinery located approximately six miles east of Evanston, Wyoming, in a rural area of Uinta County. The closest residence is approximately five miles away. The facility processes up to 4,000 barrels per day of light crude oil into gasoline. The facility was built in 1989 and operated until 1991, when it was shut down. Silver Eagle restarted the refinery in 1996, and has operated it since.



The remainder of the Executive Summary is organized as follows:"

"Section 1: Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Section 2: Overview of Regulated Substances Handled

Section 3: Worst-Case Release Scenarios

Section 4: Alternative Release Scenarios

Section 5: Accidental Release Prevention Program

Section 6: Five-Year Accident History

Section 7: Emergency Response Program

Section 8: Planned Changes to Improve Safety"



"SECTION 1: ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

SER is committed to the safety of its employees, visitors, and the public and protection of the environment in the operation of the Evanston Refinery. In addition to operating and emergency procedures, the refinery has implemented policies for: Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractors, Pre-Startup Safety Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permits, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Planning and Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets. The Emergency Respons

e Program is discussed further in Section 7."



"SECTION 2: OVERVIEW OF REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

As part of the process of refining light crude oil into gasoline, the refinery produces liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), which is a mixture primarily of C3 and C4 hydrocarbons (referred to as ""C3/C4""), which is used as fuel, blended into gasoline, or sold. The refinery also purchases LPG (either nearly pure propane or butane) for use as fuel or for gasoline blending. The LPG is stored in two pressurized bullet tanks (TK-111 and TK-112). The bullets are adjacent to each other and are connected by piping with manually-operated gate valves that are normally kept closed. Therefore, for the purposes of RMP, the tanks are considered a single ""process,"" as that term is defined in 40 CFR 68.3.



The type of LPG stored in each bullet varies, and at any time the bullets could contain nearly pure propane or nearly pure butane purchased from a supplier, or C3/C4 LPG produced by the refinery. Based on sample results, the C3/C4 LPG produced by the refinery is a combination of approximately 48% isobutane, 35% propane, 11% n-butane, 4% ethane, and 2% other liquefied petroleum gases. All of the LPGs stored in the bullets have a National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) flammability hazard rating of 4.



Each tank has a total volume capacity of 714 barrels (29,988 gallons), though maximum storage is operationally limited to 640 barrels (26,880 gallons). LPG is stored at ambient temperature, and operating pressure is dependent on temperature, but typically is in the range of 75 to 100 pounds per square inch gauge (psig), although it may go as low as 25 psig in the winter."



"SECTION 3: WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO

The worst case scenario for flammable substances is a vapor cloud explosion (VCE) with an overpressure endpoint of 1 pound per square inch (psi). The worst case scenario endpoint is based on the instantaneous release of the entire contents of the largest vessel in a

process filled to capacity resulting in a VCE. For the SER worst case scenario, it was assumed that that the valves connecting the vessels were left open and the contents of both vessels were released and both vessels contained pure butane (butane produced the greatest off-site consequence radius).



The worst case distance to a 1 psi overpressure endpoint from a VCE, based on a release of two full vessels of butane and as calculated using EPA's RMP*Comp computer model, does reach off-site. The only public receptor within the worst-case radius is a normally-unstaffed pipeline pump station, which is located on SER property. 



In accordance with 40 CFR 68.25, no active mitigation measures were considered. In addition, no administrative controls or passive mitigation were considered for this scenario."



"SECTION 4: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

Several alternative release scenarios were considered, including a pull-away explosion, piping break, pump releases due to seal failure, and overpressurization or venting through relief valves. The alternative release scenario selected is a VCE resulting from a release of flammable liquids (primarily butane) from a 6 inch piping leak. Under this scenario, the release is isolated by operators within 10 minutes. The distance to a 1 psi overpressure endpoint from a VCE, based on the alternative release scenario and as calculated using EPA's RMP*Comp computer model, does reach off-site. The only public receptor within the worst-case radius is the same normally-unstaffed pipeline pump station that was described in the worst case release scenario above. 



No active or passive mitigation systems were considered for this alternative release scenario."



"SECTION 5: ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

SER has implemented an accidental release prevention program containing the following elements (with Standard Policies developed defining requirements for each element):



Employee Participation: SER Employees assist in the de

velopment of process safety information (PSI), conduct of process hazard analysis (PHAs), development and review of operating procedures, management of change (MOC), pre-start up safety reviews (PSSR), incident investigation, and emergency response planning. Employees have access to information developed under the PSM and RMP rules through a shared drive available to all employees and an onsite library.



Process Safety Information (PSI): SER ensures that when any process equipment is ordered the following information is requested from the vendor:

Equipment Spec sheet

U1A form or equivalent

Original Engineering Calculations

Vendors installation and repair manual

All associated equipment drawings

Ensure that the equipment is fit for the service that it is in."

"Safety Data Sheets (SDS) or other relevant information about the hazards of the chemicals in the process are kept with the PSI, as are the safe upper and lower limits of the processes described in the Consequences of Deviation tables. To ensure that all PSI is maintained and readily available for personnel that need the information, SER stores all PSI in the PSM database.



Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): SER completed initial PHAs on processes covered by these standards and will revalidate PHAs in accordance with the 5 year revalidation schedule or sooner based on the complexity of changes per the MOC. PHAs are appropriate to the complexity of the process and will identify, evaluate, and control hazards in the process. The process engineer reviews the MOC and decides if a simple PHA or What-If analysis is required. The MOC Risk Assessment form determines which level of hazard analysis is required. SER normally uses one of the following methodologies to conduct PHA's: hazard and operability analysis (HAZOP), Checklist, or a combination of the two."

"Operating Procedures: SER operation personnel and refinery leaders determine the scope of the operating procedures for each unit. As procedures are develo

ped SER determines the steps to perform the procedure correctly and safely. All draft procedures are validated by at least two operators qualified in the process and go through the validation process. All SER employees involved with performing the tasks associated with any operating procedure are trained on the operating procedures.



Training: All SER employees involved with performing the tasks associated with any operating procedures are trained as described in the Plant Operator Training Guide, which requires: assigning a mentor to each employee, providing each employee with their job training guide, and completing all training identified in the guide. Training topics include the following prior to being considered qualified:

SER Safe Work Policies & Procedures

Basic Operator Topics & Tasks

Process and Equipment Overviews

Job Specific Training: Operating Procedures which include safety and health hazards specific to the unit

Affected-Level Employee Training

Awareness-Level Employee Training



Employees are trained on any design or MOC process changes prior to operating a modified process, as identified in the MOC Required Training document."

"Contractors:SER has a contractor pre-qualification process, which includes a review of the contractor safety performance. Before contractors begin work at the site, contractors attend a Site Safety Orientation and receive information about the Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) and the hazards in the areas they will be working. All contractors who work in the facility must have awareness level safety training to the nationally recognized Basic Orientation Plus Standard or equivalent and must provide proof of training for tasks appropriate to the job to be performed (such as hot work, confined space, crane operations, etc.). The method used for the training is evaluated during the pre-approval process. Contractor performance is observed and audited using a Contractor Safety Observation Checklist.



Pre-Startup S

afety Review (PSSR): Upon completion of an MOC, SER completes a PSSR for all new facilities or any facility modification (or MOC) significant enough to require a change in the PSI. The PSSR schedule is established by the MOC coordinator, with the assistance of the persons performing the PSSR. SER selects a qualified team from each of the following departments: Maintenance, Operations, Technical, Management, and Contractors (if applicable). The PSSR team validates that the equipment has been installed in accordance with specifications, and that construction was performed in accordance with specifications and the contract. The PSSR team validates that the operating, maintenance, safety and emergency procedures are in place and adequate. The PSSR team also validates all new or modified facility P&IDs been updated to show construction or process modifications. The PSSR team also verifies that action items from the PHA are complete, employees have been trained, and safety systems (such as PSVs) meet proper criteria."

"Mechanical Integrity (MI): SER includes all the following types of equipment in the MI Program: pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps (and other types of rotating equipment). SER performs inspections and tests on the equipment identified above to insure the integrity of the equipment. SER inspection and test procedures follow good engineering practices (RAGAGEP).



Hot Work Permits: The SER unit operator performs work area inspection prior to issuing a hot work permit. SER operators are the only employees allowed to issue a hot work permit. The policy describes when hot work may be allowed or would be prohibited, requirements for fire watch, and requirements for the contents of the hot work permit."

"Management of Change (MOC): MOCs are completed using a Request for Change Review and Approval Form for changes that are not a replacement-in-kind. Tasks comple

ted for each MOC include:

List technical basis for the change.

Determine health and safety impacts by completing the MOC Departmental Review & Concurrence form.

Document action items and provide completion documentation to MOC Coordinator.

Redline all affected documents, such as P&ID's and operating procedures.

A representative from each Department must review and sign and ultimately the plant manager must provide final rejection or approval in order to implement the proposed change.

Determine the level of hazard analysis necessary for the proposed change.

Assign action items from PHA and write work orders for each task.

Complete a long-form PSSR prior to start-up of any changes.

The MOC must be signed by the MOC Coordinator, Operations, Maintenance and Plant managers prior to implementing the proposed change."

"Incident Investigation: SER will begin any incident investigation as soon as possible and always within 48 hours of the incident. The facility has implemented a software system for tracking incident and near miss investigations and follow up.



Emergency Planning and Response: As described further in Section 7.



Compliance Audits:  The facility maintains a calendar for PSM and RMP PHAs and compliance audits. The most recent RMP compliance audit was performed in 2020."



"SECTION 6: FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases from a RMP covered process in the past five years that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage."



"SECTION 7: EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has a written Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) with emergency response procedures for releases of LPG, fires, and other emergencies. The ERAP has been sent to the Evanston Fire Department, Uinta County Fire District, and the Evanston Regional Hospital. The facility has a Memorandum of Understanding with the

Uinta County Fire District for fire and rescue services."



"SECTION 8: PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

SER plans to make the following changes by the end of 2022 to improve safety:

Upgrade the burner management system (BMS) for the Hot Oil Heater

Install foam suppression system on Tank 106

Build the new truck loading shelter with an installed fire suppression system"
